comments.body: We have `hdfs`, which we name [`python-hdfs`](https://github.com/conda-forge/python-hdfs-feedstock). Maybe we should do the same here. Thoughts?
`hdfs3` is a Python wrapper to the `libhdfs3` C++ library, so we named it accordingly. `python-hdfs3` might add more confusion to the namespace of HDFS-related libraries.

> `python-hdfs3` might add more confusion to the namespace of HDFS-related libraries.

I don't think so. Most Linux distros do that. Renaming is confusing, but we are only suggesting a prefix :grin:

If possible, I'd prefer to leave this package named `hdfs3` here to match our github repo, docs, pypi, etc. and keep things simple, where `hdfs3` is the Python library that wraps `libhdfs3`. There are packages on pypi named `hdfs`, `pywebhdfs`, `py4hdfs`, `python-hdfs`, `webhdfspy`, `pywebhdfs`, and so on, I think it would be confusing to have `hdfs3` on pypi and `python-hdfs3` on conda-forge.

We had a discussion in our general meeting recently and agreed to always prefix Python packages with `python-`. Given that `conda` is a language agnostic packaging tool and new packages from other languages are being added/proposed regularly, it makes sense to us to do the prefixing to keep track of what language this relates to. Once that is addressed, we will be happy to merge this nice recipe.
What are the roadblocks to having this running on other platforms?  Is there interest in getting it running on other platforms?  It would be nice to add a comment here about why it is linux-only.

This library is a wrapper to the `libhdfs3` C++ library, which interacts with data in HDFS. HDFS is primarily deployed on Linux platforms as part of Hadoop installations, e.g., using Cloudera CDH or Hortonworks HDP, which are Linux only. So we only target Linux for this library and haven't had any requests otherwise.
